_(Learn how and when to remove this message)_  
  
The **economy ofPalau** consists primarily of tourism, fishing and subsistence
agriculture. The government is the major employer of the work force, relying
heavily on financial assistance from the United States. The population enjoys
a per capita income of more than twice that of the Philippines and much of
Micronesia. Long-term prospects for the tourist sector have been greatly
bolstered by the expansion of air travel in the Pacific and the rising
prosperity of leading East Asian countries.

Palau's per capita GDP of $17,000 makes it one of the wealthier Pacific Island
states. Nominal GDP increased by an annual average of nearly 14% from 1983 to
1990, and by an annual rate of over 10% from 1991 to 1997. Growth turned
sharply negative in 1998 and 1999 as a result of the 1997 Asian financial
crisis.
openai_summarised_points: • The economy of Palau is primarily based on tourism, fishing, and subsistence agriculture, which constitute the main sectors supporting the nation’s economic activities.
• The government of Palau is the largest employer within the workforce and depends significantly on financial assistance from the United States to sustain its operations and public services.

• Palau’s population enjoys a per capita income that is more than double that of the Philippines and much of the Micronesian region, indicating a relatively higher standard of living compared to neighboring countries.

• The long-term prospects for Palau’s tourism sector have been substantially strengthened by the expansion of air travel across the Pacific region and the increasing economic prosperity of major East Asian countries.
• Palau’s per capita Gross Domestic Product (GDP) stands at approximately $17,000, positioning it as one of the wealthier Pacific Island states in terms of income levels.
• From 1983 to 1990, Palau experienced a nominal GDP growth averaging nearly 14% annually, reflecting a period of rapid economic expansion.
• Between 1991 and 1997, the economy continued to grow robustly, with an annual nominal GDP growth rate exceeding 10%.
• However, economic growth reversed sharply in 1998 and 1999, turning negative due to the adverse impacts of the 1997 Asian financial crisis on the region.

text:
Tourism is Palau's main industry. Activity focuses on scuba diving and
snorkeling among the islands' rich marine environment, including the Floating
Garden Islands to the west of Koror. Major scuba diving sites include German
Channel and Blue Corner. The number of visitors—85% of whom come from Japan,
Taiwan, and the U.S.—reached nearly 67,000 in 1997, more than quadruple the
level of a decade earlier. Tourism earned $67 million in foreign exchange for
Palau in 1996, (which is 1,000 dollars per person) accounting for roughly half
of GDP. Arrivals from Asian countries dropped in 1998 and 1999 due to the
regional economic downturn and the depreciation of many Asian currencies
against the dollar, which made Palau's dollar-denominated prices more
expensive.

The service sector dominates the Palauan economy, contributing more than 80%
of GDP and employing three-quarters of the work force. The government alone
employs nearly 30% of workers. One of the government's main responsibilities
is administering external assistance. Under the terms of the Compact of Free
Association with the United States, Palau will receive more than $450 million
in assistance over 15 years, $30 million per year, and is eligible to
participate in more than 40 federal programs. The first grant of $142 million
was made in 1994. Further annual payments in lesser amounts will be made
through 2009. U.S. grants in 1999 totaled $24 million.

Construction is the most important industrial activity, contributing over 9%
of GDP. Several large infrastructure projects, including the rebuilding of the
bridge connecting Koror and Babeldaob Islands after its collapse in 1996 and
the construction of a highway around the rim of Babeldaob, boosted activity at
the end of the 1990s.

Agriculture is mainly on a subsistence level, the principal crops being
coconuts, root crops, and bananas. Fishing is a potential source of revenue,
but the islands' tuna output dropped by over one-third during the 1990s.

There are no Patent Laws in Palau. Gazetteer – Patents Archived 2018-09-26 at
the Wayback Machine
openai_summarised_points: • Tourism constitutes the primary industry of Palau, with activities centered on scuba diving and snorkeling within the islands' rich marine environment, notably including the Floating Garden Islands located to the west of Koror.
• Prominent scuba diving sites in Palau include the German Channel and Blue Corner, attracting significant tourist interest.

• In 1997, the number of visitors to Palau reached nearly 67,000, representing more than a fourfold increase compared to a decade earlier; approximately 85% of these visitors originated from Japan, Taiwan, and the United States.

• Tourism generated $67 million in foreign exchange earnings for Palau in 1996, equating to approximately $1,000 per capita, and accounted for roughly half of the nation’s Gross Domestic Product (GDP).

• Tourist arrivals from Asian countries declined in 1998 and 1999 due to the regional economic downturn and the depreciation of many Asian currencies against the U.S. dollar, which increased the cost of Palau’s dollar-denominated prices for Asian visitors.
• The service sector dominates Palau’s economy, contributing over 80% of GDP and employing approximately 75% of the workforce.
• The government is a major employer, accounting for nearly 30% of total employment, and plays a key role in administering external assistance programs.

• Under the Compact of Free Association with the United States, Palau is scheduled to receive more than $450 million in assistance over a 15-year period, averaging $30 million annually, and is eligible to participate in over 40 U.S. federal programs.
• The initial grant under this Compact amounted to $142 million, disbursed in 1994, with subsequent smaller annual payments continuing through 2009; U.S. grants totaled $24 million in 1999.

• Construction represents the most significant industrial activity in Palau, contributing over 9% of GDP, with major infrastructure projects in the late 1990s including the rebuilding of the bridge connecting Koror and Babeldaob Islands after its collapse in 1996 and the construction of a highway encircling Babeldaob.
• Agriculture in Palau is primarily subsistence-based, with principal crops comprising coconuts, root crops, and bananas.
• Fishing holds potential as a revenue source; however, tuna output from the islands declined by more than one-third during the 1990s.
• Palau does not have patent laws in place, as indicated by the absence of patent legislation and archival references such as the Gazetteer – Patents (archived September 26, 2018).

text:
The main economic challenge confronting Palau is to ensure the long-term
viability of its economy by reducing its reliance on foreign assistance. Palau
has created a trust fund to be drawn upon after the cessation of Compact
grants, the value of which had grown to $140 million by the beginning of 2009.
Also, in the late 1990s, Palau was affected by the 1997 Asian Financial
Crisis, and their economy suffered. The island took a huge hit during the
COVID-19 pandemic with global travel restrictions putting tourism to a halt.
The Asian Development Bank projects that the GDP of Palau contracted by 9.5%
in 2020.

Historically, the United States has provided substantial assistance to Palau.
Japan and Taiwan have provided funding for infrastructure projects in Palau.
openai_summarised_points: • The primary economic challenge facing Palau is ensuring the long-term sustainability of its economy by decreasing dependence on foreign assistance.
• To address this challenge, Palau established a trust fund intended to provide financial resources after the end of Compact grants; this fund had grown to a value of $140 million by early 2009.
• In the late 1990s, Palau’s economy was adversely affected by the 1997 Asian Financial Crisis, which caused significant economic difficulties for the island nation.
• The COVID-19 pandemic severely impacted Palau’s economy, as global travel restrictions led to a complete halt in tourism, a critical sector for the country.
• According to projections by the Asian Development Bank, Palau’s Gross Domestic Product (GDP) contracted by 9.5% in the year 2020 due to the pandemic’s effects.
• Historically, the United States has been a major provider of substantial economic assistance to Palau, supporting its development and economic stability.
• Additionally, Japan and Taiwan have contributed funding specifically targeted at infrastructure projects within Palau, aiding in the country’s development efforts.

text:
In order to tackle mass tourism, the Palau Legacy Project, a sustainable
tourism body, created a visa policy for the island of Palau to protect the
nation from environmental damage. The "Palau Pledge" was the most awarded
campaign of 2018 according to the WARC Creative 100 index.
openai_summarised_points: • The Palau Legacy Project, an organization dedicated to sustainable tourism, implemented a visa policy specifically for the island of Palau to mitigate the negative environmental impacts associated with mass tourism.
• This visa policy was designed as a protective measure to preserve Palau’s natural environment from potential damage caused by large numbers of tourists.

• The "Palau Pledge," a campaign associated with this sustainable tourism initiative, was recognized as the most awarded campaign of 2018 according to the WARC Creative 100 index, highlighting its global acclaim and effectiveness in promoting responsible tourism.

**Gross Domestic Product (GDP)** : purchasing power parity – $132 million
(2009 est.) (GDP estimate includes U.S. subsidy)

**GDP – real growth rate** : 1% (2009 est.)

**GDP – per capita** : purchasing power parity – $8 500 (2009 est.)

**GDP – composition by sector**

* _agriculture_ : N/A
* _industry_ : N/A
* _services_ : N/A

**Population below poverty line** : N/A

**Household income or consumption by percentage share**

* _lowest 10%_ : N/A
* _highest 10%_ : N/A
openai_summarised_points: • The Gross Domestic Product (GDP) of Palau, measured by purchasing power parity, was estimated at $132 million in 2009, with this estimate including subsidies received from the United States.
• In 2009, Palau's real GDP growth rate was approximately 1%, indicating modest economic expansion during that year.
• The GDP per capita of Palau, based on purchasing power parity, was estimated to be $8,500 in 2009, reflecting the average economic output per person.
• Detailed data on the GDP composition by sector—specifically agriculture, industry, and services—are not available (N/A) for Palau.
• Information regarding the percentage of the population living below the poverty line in Palau is not available (N/A).
• Data on household income or consumption distribution by percentage share, including the lowest 10% and highest 10% income groups, are not available (N/A).
• The inflation rate in Palau, measured by consumer prices, was estimated at 3.4% in the year 2000.

text:
**Labor force** : 10 200 (2000)

**Labor force – by occupation**

* _Agriculture_ : 20%
* _Industry_ : N/A
* _Services_ : N/A

(1990)

**Unemployment rate** : 4.2% (2000 est.)
openai_summarised_points: • The labor force of Palau was recorded at 10,200 individuals in the year 2000.
• In 1990, the distribution of the labor force by occupation in Palau indicated that 20% were employed in agriculture.
• Data for the labor force distribution in industry and services sectors for the year 1990 are not available (N/A).
• The estimated unemployment rate in Palau was 4.2% as of the year 2000.

text:
* _Revenues_ : $57.81 million
* _Expenditures_ : $80.8 million, including capital expenditures of $17.1 million (FY 98/99 est.)
openai_summarised_points: • The government of Palau reported total revenues amounting to $57.81 million for the fiscal year 1998/1999.
• Total expenditures for Palau during the fiscal year 1998/1999 were estimated at $80.8 million.
• Included within the total expenditures, capital expenditures accounted for $17.1 million in the fiscal year 1998/1999.

text:
Dominant industries include tourism, craft items (from shell, wood, pearls),
construction, and garment making.

**Industrial production growth rate** : N/A
openai_summarised_points: • The dominant industries in Palau encompass tourism, the production of craft items made from shell, wood, and pearls, construction, and garment manufacturing.
• The industrial production growth rate for Palau is not available (N/A).

text:
**Electricity – production** : 200 MWh (1996)

**Electricity – production by source**

* _Fossil fuels_ : 85%
* _Hydro_ : 15%
* _Nuclear_ : 0%
* _Other_ : 0%

(1996)

**Electricity – consumption** : 200 MWh (1996)

**Electricity – exports** : 0 kWh (1996)

**Electricity – imports** : 0 kWh (1996)
openai_summarised_points: • In 1996, Palau's total electricity production amounted to 200 megawatt-hours (MWh).
• The composition of electricity production in Palau in 1996 was predominantly from fossil fuels, which accounted for 85% of the total electricity generated.
• Hydroelectric power contributed 15% to Palau's electricity production in 1996.
• There was no electricity production from nuclear sources in Palau in 1996, with nuclear energy accounting for 0% of the total.
• Other sources of electricity production besides fossil fuels and hydroelectric power were nonexistent in Palau in 1996, representing 0% of the total electricity production.
• Palau's electricity consumption in 1996 was equal to its production, totaling 200 MWh.
• The country did not export any electricity in 1996, with electricity exports recorded at 0 kilowatt-hours (kWh).
• Similarly, Palau did not import any electricity in 1996, with electricity imports also recorded at 0 kWh.

text:
**Agriculture – products** : coconuts, copra, cassava (tapioca), sweet
potatoes

**Exports** : $18 million (f.o.b., 2001)

**Exports – commodities** : trochus (type of shellfish), tuna, copra,
handicrafts

**Exports – partners** : Japan 70.1%, South Korea 15.1% United States 7.1%
(2019)

**Imports** : $99 million (f.o.b., 2001 est.)

**Imports – commodities** : machinery and equipment, fuels, metals, foodstuffs

**Imports – partners** : South Korea 18.7%, China 18.2%, Taiwan 16.9%, United
States 16.5%, Japan 16%, (2019)
openai_summarised_points: • The primary agricultural products of Palau include coconuts, copra, cassava (tapioca), and sweet potatoes.
• In 2001, Palau's total exports were valued at $18 million (free on board, f.o.b.).
• The main export commodities from Palau consist of trochus (a type of shellfish), tuna, copra, and handicrafts.
• As of 2019, Palau's export partners were predominantly Japan, accounting for 70.1% of exports, followed by South Korea with 15.1%, and the United States with 7.1%.
• Palau's imports were estimated at $99 million (f.o.b.) in 2001.
• The principal import commodities include machinery and equipment, fuels, metals, and foodstuffs.
• In 2019, Palau's import partners were South Korea at 18.7%, China at 18.2%, Taiwan at 16.9%, the United States at 16.5%, and Japan at 16%.

text:
**Debt – external** : $18.4 Billion (2014 estimate). Palau ranks as one of the
countries with the highest external debt as a share of GDP.

**Economic aid – recipient** : $155.8 million. Note: the Compact of Free
Association with the U.S., entered into after the end of the UN trusteeship on
1 October 1994, provides Palau with up to $700 million in U.S. aid over 15
years in return for furnishing military facilities.
openai_summarised_points: • As of 2014, Palau's external debt was estimated at $18.4 billion, positioning the country among those with the highest external debt relative to their Gross Domestic Product (GDP).
• Palau received economic aid amounting to $155.8 million.

• The Compact of Free Association between Palau and the United States, established following the conclusion of the United Nations trusteeship on 1 October 1994, commits the U.S. to provide Palau with up to $700 million in aid over a 15-year period.
• In exchange for this aid, Palau agrees to furnish military facilities to the United States under the terms of the Compact of Free Association.
